Catalytic oxidation of toluene by ozone at ambient temperature is a promising, energy-efficient method. However, challenges such as catalyst poisoning and deactivation remain significant obstacles. As such, understanding the deactivation mechanisms and the regeneration of catalysts is crucial for optimizing catalytic oxidation processes. This study investigates the deactivation and regeneration processes of Mn/MOR catalysts in the ozone-mediated oxidation of toluene. The highest toluene removal efficiency achieved was 92.3 % with a manganese loading of 1 wt. %, but after eight experimental cycles, the catalytic performance declined to 24.3 %. The deactivation of the catalyst was primarily attributed to the accumulation of by-products during toluene degradation, the loss of Mn3+, and the reduction in oxygen vacancies. Regeneration experiments demonstrated that exposure to hot air effectively oxidized intermediate products and restored the active sites, recovering 94.2 % of the initial catalytic performance. Additionally, the possible reaction pathway for toluene degradation was deduced through GC–MS analysis. This work demonstrates the possibility of recovery of this deactivated catalyst and provides ideas for whole-life catalyst management. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mn/MOR Ozone Toluene Deactivation Regeneration Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid advancement of industrialization and the modernization of living standards, the global greenhouse effect has intensified, leading to frequent occurrences of various climate disasters. To address global climate change, controlling air pollution has become an urgent priority [1]. From 2016 to 2020, significant progress was made in air pollution prevention and control. However, ozone concentrations have increased rather than decreased. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from human activities are key precursors to ozone pollution [2]. Therefore, strengthening VOCs management is a critical strategy to reduce ozone pollution and mitigate hazy weather conditions. Currently, common technologies for treating VOCs include adsorption [3], photocatalysis [4], catalytic oxidation [5], non-thermal plasma [6], and catalytic ozonation [7]. Among these methods, catalytic oxidation stands out due to its lower energy consumption and ability to directly mineralize VOCs into CO x . Catalytic ozone oxidation degrades VOCs at room temperature and promotes the conversion of metal ions to higher oxidation states [8], thereby achieving more efficient VOCs treatment. In catalytic ozone oxidation of VOCs, manganese-based catalysts exhibited excellent ozone decomposition capacity and catalytic activity. Huang et al. [9] introduced K⁺ into manganese oxide (MnO x ) by the hydrothermal method, which significantly increased the contents of Mn3+ and lattice oxygen, enhanced the oxidation ability of the MnO x catalyst for toluene, and achieved a 90 % toluene conversion rate at low temperatures. Lin et al. [10] synthesized the Mn@ZMS293 catalyst with a confinement effect. When used in combination with ozone, the conversion rate of CH₃SH can reach 100 %. Wen et al. [11] synthesized the Ag/MnO2 catalyst with a strong electron metal-support interaction. Ag and oxygen vacancies promote the conversion of ozone into reactive oxygen, improving the toluene conversion rate and effectively degrading intermediates into CO2. Selecting a suitable support is a key factor in enhancing catalytic activity. Molecular sieves have advantages such as a large specific surface area, strong adsorption capacity, and abundant acidic sites. They have gradually become one of the commonly used supports in the field of ozone catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds. Dong et al. [12] found that MnO x /MCM-41 formed a Si-O-Mn structure, which gave it excellent electron transfer capability and the catalyst was rich in surface reactive oxygen species. Li et al. [13] achieved 90 % toluene conversion by loading Ag on Mn/HZSM-5 (3:1 ratio of Mn to Ag), which improved the mobility of lattice oxygen and ozone decomposition on the catalyst surface. However, the molecular sieve catalyst loaded with active metals will exhibit a decrease in both activity and CO x selectivity as time elapses [14,15]. Catalyst deactivation is primarily attributed to factors such as metal sintering, carbon accumulation, and poisoning. In the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, the deposition of carbonaceous material on the catalyst surface and within its pores is a common cause of deactivation. This deposition obstructs the contact between target pollutants and active sites, thereby reducing catalytic efficiency and mineralization rates [16]. Marta Díaz et al. [14] investigated the deactivation of the HZSM-5 catalyst in the oligomerization of 1-butene and identified the clogging of oligomers (soft coke) in the catalyst matrix as the main cause of deactivation. Fang et al. [17] found that as the reaction temperature increased, the mass transfer of O2 on the catalyst surface became less efficient than that of benzene, leading to carbon buildup. This, along with oxide clustering on the surface at high temperatures, contributed to catalyst deactivation. Although the above studies have concluded that carbon deposition is a key factor hindering the catalytic reaction, the relationship between carbon deposition and the loss of active sites remains unclear. In this study, advanced characterization techniques were utilized to elucidate in detail that the deactivation of catalysts is a process driven by the coupling of multiple factors. Various methods have been explored to control and reduce carbon deposition on catalysts. For example, the production of carbon deposition can be mitigated by modifying the catalyst. Li et al. [18] found that the Cu-modified cerium oxide (CeO2) catalyst has abundant oxygen vacancies. A high concentration of oxygen vacancies can accelerate the consumption of intermediate products and effectively inhibit their generation. Kim et al. [19] reduced the oxidation temperature of coke by loading platinum (Pt) and gadolinium (Gd) onto ZSM-5, and the synergistic effect of Pt and Gd helped stabilize the catalyst, improving oil and gas yield during cracking and regeneration. Park et al. [20] incorporated CeO2 into a nickel-based catalyst and found that CeO2 inhibited carbon deposition during the autothermal reforming of toluene. Despite these advances, catalyst deactivation remains inevitable, though it can be mitigated through methods like oxygen combustion. Benamar et al. [21] calcined coked zeolite samples at 500 °C for 3 h under nitrogen, air, and hydrogen atmospheres and found that the decoking effect followed the order Air > H2 > N2. Marta Díaz et al. [14] removed soft coke at 400 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. However, these studies have focused on thermal regeneration, neglecting the more energy-efficient methods of water wash regeneration and ozone regeneration. In this work, the unique properties of ozone-catalyzed oxidation were exploited to compare the performance recovery of in-situ ozone regeneration and water washing with other regeneration methods. Therefore, manganese-loaded molecular sieve catalysts (Mn/MOR) were synthesized or the ozone oxidation of toluene, a typical representative of VOCs. The study systematically investigated the effect of manganese loading on catalytic performance, revealed the multi-factor synergistic mechanism of catalyst deactivation, and proposed effective regeneration strategies. The reaction pathway of toluene degradation was deduced through gas-phase extraction methods. This study provides valuable insights for the future design of catalysts and the realization of resource utilization. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of manganese-loaded molecular sieve catalysts Manganese oxides were dispersed onto H-MOR (Si/Al ratio of 25) using the impregnation method. First, 8 g of H-MOR was mixed with deionized water and stirred for 5 min. Then, a solution containing X wt. % (X = 0.5, 1, 5, 10) of 50 % Mn(NO3)2 was added to the suspension. The mixture was sonicated for 90 min and stirred for 6 h. Afterward, the suspension was dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C and calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 180 min. The prepared samples were labeled as 0.5 wt. % Mn/MOR, 1 wt. % Mn/MOR, 5 wt. % Mn/MOR, and 10 wt. % Mn/MOR, and were then screened to a particle size of 40–60 mesh for catalytic activity testing. 2.2 Measurement of ozone concentration The concentration of ozone was determined using the iodometric method. First, 4 mL of 20 % KI solution was added to a 125 mL absorption bottle, followed by 76 mL of deionized water. Ozone was then passed into the absorption bottle for 2 min, during which the total volume of absorbed gas was 2.8 L. After sampling, 1 mL of sulfuric acid solution (with a volume ratio of sulfuric acid to water of 1:5) was immediately added, and the mixture was shaken thoroughly and allowed to stand for 5 min. The solution was then titrated with 0.1000 mol/L standard sodium thiosulfate solution. Once the solution turned pale yellow, a few drops of starch solution were added, and titration continued carefully and rapidly until the color disappeared. The ozone concentration was calculated based on the consumption of sodium thiosulfate solution. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalyst activity evaluation experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed reactor, using quartz tubes with an inner diameter of 8 mm as the reaction vessels. The simulated flue gas was supplied by bottled gas from Nanjing Changyuan Gas Co (C7H8–40 ppm/balance N2, N2–99.999 %, Air-99.999 %). Ozone is generated by air flowing through the MFC (S500-AR111) controller into the ozone generator (YE-XS230717). The gas flow rate is 1.4 L/min and the gas space-time velocity (GHSV) is 28,000 h-1. 3 mL of catalyst were placed at the center of the quartz tube, and the reaction gas flowed into the tube after passing through a mixing chamber. The initial concentrations of toluene and ozone were 20 ppm and 300 ppm, respectively. The 1 wt. % Mn/MOR catalyst, which exhibited the highest catalytic activity, was selected for subsequent deactivation and regeneration experiments. The deactivation experiments were conducted after a prolonged reaction time of 1500 min, while thermal regeneration was performed in a tube furnace. The gases exiting the catalytic reactor were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC-9660) to measure CO, CO2, and toluene concentrations, and the residual ozone was quantified using the iodometric method. Prior to the activity evaluation, the catalyst was first saturated with toluene adsorption, after which ozone was injected into the simulated flue gas. Toluene removal rate, Ozone removal rate, CO selectivity and CO2 selectivity were expressed as [Toluene]conversion, [Ozone]conversion, [CO]selectivity and [CO2]selectivity, respectively. Their values were calculated as follows: (2–1–) [ Toluene ] conversion = [ Toluene ] in − [ Toluene ] out [ Toluene ] in × 100 % (2–2–) [ Ozone ] conversion = c ( O 3 ) in − c ( O 3 ) out c ( O 3 ) in × 100 % (2–3–) [ CO ] selectivity = c ( CO ) 7 ( [ Toluene ] in − [ Toluene ] out ) × 100 % (2–4–) [ CO 2 ] selectivity = c ( C O 2 ) 7 ( [ Toluene ] in − [ Toluene ] out ) × 100 % Where [Toluene]in represents the initial toluene concentration (ppm); [Toluene]out represents the reacted toluene outlet concentration (ppm); c(O3)in is the initial ozone concentration (ppm); c(O3)out represents the reacted ozone outlet concentration (ppm); and the carbon monoxide outlet concentration (ppm) is represented by c(CO); c(CO2) represents the carbon dioxide outlet concentration (ppm). 2.4 Catalyst characterization The crystalline phase of the samples was tested and analyzed by X-ray polycrystalline diffraction (XRD, Smartlab 9KW) with a Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15405 nm, 40 mV, 200 mA). The scanning range was 2θ = 5°−90°, with a scanning rate of 5 °/min. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using an ASAP2460 analyzer. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and the pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The surface morphology was examined using a thermal field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Zeiss Gemini 300). Elemental valences and concentrations on the sample surface were analyzed using a Thermo Scientific™ Nexsa™ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) instrument, focusing on the Mn2p and O1s orbitals in the Mn valence state, with a monochromatic Al-Kα ray source. The redox properties of the catalyst were characterized using H2-TPR (AutoChem1-II-2920). For this analysis, 50 mg of the sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube, dried, and pre-treated by heating from room temperature to 350 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, followed by purging with He gas (50 mL/min) for 1 hour. The sample was then cooled to 50 °C and exposed to a 10 % H2/Ar mixture (50 mL/min) for 30 min. After the baseline stabilized, the sample was desorbed at 800 °C in a 10 % H2/Ar stream, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the reducing gases were detected by TCD. Oxygenated organic deposition on the catalyst was determined by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) using a thermobalance (TP-5080-B). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under an air atmosphere using a NETZSCH STA-449-F5 instrument (Germany). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Mn/MOR catalytic performance experiments The room temperature catalytic activity and CO x concentration for different Mn/MOR catalysts during 100 min of reaction are shown in Fig. 1 a,b. It can be observed that the 1 wt. % Mn/MOR catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity among all catalysts ([Toluene]conversion = 92.3 %; [Ozone]conversion = 100 %). The 1 wt. % Mn/MOR catalyst also exhibited the highest CO2 selectivity ([CO2]selectivity = 51.65 %). Therefore, the 1 wt. % Mn/MOR catalyst was selected for the subsequent cyclic activity tests. Fig. 1c,d show the toluene conversion and CO x concentrations progressively decreased over the 8 cycles. By hour 40, toluene conversion decreased to 24.3 % and CO x selectivity decreased to 39.9 %, indicating significant accumulation of reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface [6]. Some examples of catalysts used for ozone-catalyzed toluene and the corresponding properties are listed in Table S1. By comparing the activity of the Mn/MOR catalyst prepared in this paper with that of the catalysts reported in existing literatures, the Mn/MOR catalyst shows superior catalytic activity. 3.2 Deactivation characteristics of 1 wt. % Mn/MOR catalysts 3.2.1 Physical and morphological structures analysis A series of investigations were carried out to investigate the mechanisms of reaction poisoning and inactivation. As shown in the XRD result (Fig. 2 a), both fresh and post catalysts retained the diffraction peaks of the carrier at 23.8°, and diffraction peaks of MnO2 (PDF 01–073–2509) were also evident. Integrating of the MnO2 characteristic peaks showed a decrease in peak area from 11,284 a.u. (fresh catalyst) 9929 a.u. (deactivated catalyst), representing a 12 % reduction in tensity. The diminished peak intensity in the deactivated catalyst indicates reduced crystallinity, likely caused by agglomeration of MnO x species on the surface [22]. The structures of fresh and post catalysts were tested by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments and the results are shown in Fig. 2b According to the adsorption isotherm classification by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), the isotherms of the Mn/MOR catalysts were classified as type I with H4-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of microporous structures. Additionally, the N2 adsorption-desorption curves of the used catalysts did not fully close, which may be attributed to the deposition of intermediates at the catalyst channel inlet, leaving the interior of the catalyst unblocked and preventing complete desorption [23]. Table 1 presents the changes in specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts before and after the reaction. The BET surface area and pore volume of the used catalysts decreased by 16.75 % and 16.67 %, respectively, further suggesting the formation of carbon deposits on the catalysts after the reaction. Most of the carbon deposits accumulated on the surface, while a smaller portion clogged the internal pore channels. Carbon deposits not only reduce the specific surface area of the catalyst, but also cover the active sites on the catalyst surface. This hinders the interaction between the catalyst and toluene, decreasing the toluene degradation rate. The surface morphology of the catalysts before and after the reaction was characterized, as shown in Fig. 3 . It can be observed that the catalyst morphology changed significantly after the reaction, with a layer of carbon deposits covering it. To further elucidate the formation of these carbon deposits, the changes in elemental concentration in the catalyst before and after the reaction were analyzed (Fig. 4 ). The results clearly show that the Mn element is highly dispersed, and the well-dispersed MnO x facilitates the interaction between organic compounds and the catalyst during the reaction. Additionally, the carbon content (C) increased by 2.1 % after the reaction, indicating the deposition of carbonaceous material on the catalyst surface. 3.2.2 Redox ability and surface elemental analysis To further investigate the effect of carbon accumulation on the redox capacity of the catalyst, the H2-TPR analysis was conducted (Fig. 5 a). The spectrum shows multiple reduction peaks. The reduction peaks of the fresh catalysts at 198 °C and 232 °C are attributed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species on oxygen vacancies [24]. The reduction peak at 268 °C corresponds to the reduction of MnO2(IV) to Mn2O3(III); the peak at 362 °C is attributed to the reduction of Mn2O3(III) to Mn3O4(III and IV); and the peak at 525 °C is assigned to the reduction of Mn3O4(III and IV) to MnO(II) [12,15]. The reduction peaks of post catalysts (290, 373, and 441 °C) are the reduction peaks of MnO2 to Mn2O3, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and Mn3O4 to MnO respectively [25]. It can be observed that the area of the reduction peak for Mn3+ is smaller, and the temperature of the lowest reduction peak has shifted to higher values, indicating a decrease in the redox capacity of the catalysts after deactivation. To investigate the surface chemistry of the catalysts, XPS analysis was performed to examine the changes in the valence states and elemental content of the catalyst before and after the reaction. The wide-scan XPS spectrum in Fig. S1 shows the catalyst with distinct Mn2p, C1s, and O1s peaks. In particular, the Mn2p3/2 spectrum (Fig. 5b) can be deconvoluted into two characteristic peaks at 641.90–641.98 eV and 643.92–643.95 eV, corresponding to Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [26]. The binding energies and contents of each valence state of Mn are shown in Table 2 . The results showed that the Mn3+ content in the fresh catalyst was high, with an Mn3+/Mn ratio of 65.68 %. The reduced Mn3+ content of the post-catalyst is consistent with the H2-TPR results, indicating that the catalyst loses Mn(III) during the ozonation process. Numerous studies have proved that the catalytic activity was positively correlated with the Mn3+ content [27,28]. The presence of Mn3+ could enhance the electron transfer capacity of the catalyst surface and promote the production of oxygen vacancies [29]. As shown in Eq. (3–1) (where O v denotes oxygen vacancies), oxygen vacancies are generated when Mn3+ is present to maintain electrostatic equilibrium [30,31], which has also been shown to facilitate ozone decomposition, thereby enhancing organic matter degradation [5]. (3–1–) 4 M n 4 + + O 2 − → 4 M n 4 + 2 e − / O v + 1 / 2 O 2 → 2 M n 4 + + 2 M n 3 + + O v + 1 / 2 O 2 Fig. 5c shows the XPS spectrum of O1s, which was analyzed and deconvoluted into three peaks. The peak with lower binding energy at ∼530.89 eV is lattice oxygen (denoted as O latt ) [32], and the peak at ∼532.61 eV is attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as O vac ) [33]. In addition, the characteristic peak at ∼533.86 eV corresponds to adsorbed water (H2O or OH-, denoted as O γ ). It is generally believed that O vac plays a dominant role in the oxidation of toluene at low temperatures [34]. The content of O vac is shown in Table 2. According to Eq. (3–1), it can be deduced that the jump of the valence state of manganese ions is the key to the generation of oxygen vacancies. The consumed oxygen vacancies could not be replenished in time, leading to a decrease in the oxygen vacancy content of the post-catalyst. 3.2.3 Characterization of carbon deposited on fresh and post catalyst surfaces The thermogravimetric results of the fresh and post catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 a. It can be seen that the post-catalyst exhibits significant weight loss compared to the fresh catalyst. To distinguish the sources of weight loss at different stages, the TG-MS hyphenated technique was employed to monitor the composition and content of the evolved gases in real-time, and the results are presented in Fig. S2. The weight loss of the fresh catalyst in the temperature range of 20–300 °C is due to the desorption of adsorbed water and hydroxyl groups [35]. For the post-catalyst, the desorption of water vapor occurs in the range of 20–100 °C. During this process, the H2O signal gradually increases and then levels off. Moreover, the signal of the fresh catalyst is stronger than that of the post-catalyst, which may be due to the conversion of hydroxyl groups into H2O upon desorption on the fresh catalyst. The slight weight loss of the fresh catalyst in the range of 587–752 °C can be attributed to the transformation of MnO2 to Mn3O4 [36], and this process is accompanied by the release of O2 [37]. Therefore, it can be observed that the O2 signal generally shows a downward trend in the range of 25–500 °C, while in the range of 600–711 °C, the trend is gentle with a slight increase in peak intensity. The post-catalyst shows significant weight loss in the range of 100–300 °C. This can be attributed to the conversion and decomposition of highly reactive deposited carbon [38]. During this process, distinct CO2 and CO signals can be observed. According to the fact that the O₂ signal of the post-catalyst gradually increases after 300 °C in Fig. S2a, and the CO2 and CO signals keep rising, it is speculated that the weight loss in the range of 300–542 °C may be the combined effect of the oxidative decomposition of less reactive deposited carbon and the transformation of MnO2 to Mn2O3 [39,40]. To gain insight into the nature of the deposited carbon, TPO experiments were performed on both fresh and post-reaction catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6b The first oxidation peaks (264 °C and 297 °C) in both fresh and post catalysts are attributed to the presence of H2O in the catalysts [41]. The oxidation peak at 609 °C is related to the presence of structurally ordered or less active deposited carbon, which results from the catalytic reaction [23]. In general, the peaks at 350 °C to 500 °C are associated with more active deposited carbon [42]. Combined with the GC–MS results, the oxidation peak at 452 °C is considered to be oxygenated organic carbon. The results of the mass spectrometry analyses of the tail gas components during the TPO analysis are presented in Fig. S3. It was observed that CO2 was released between 302 °C and 693 °C, while CO was produced between 311 °C and 687 °C. These findings are consistent with the thermal analysis results of the post-reaction catalyst, further confirming that carbonaceous material accumulation is the primary cause of catalyst deactivation. 3.2.4 GC–MS analysis of carbon deposits on post catalyst surfaces To investigate the products of the ozone-catalyzed oxidation of toluene, dichlorotoluene was used to extract the carbonaceous material on the catalyst surface and the gas-phase products of the reaction. Fig. 7 a shows the gas-phase degradation products. Among them, the characteristic peaks at the retention times of 4.669 min, 6.791 min and 8.832 min are attributed to the substances with Si-O structures on the chromatographic column. The catalyst surface product peaks are shown in Fig. 7b and the corresponding substances are listed in Table 3 and 4 . These results indicate that benzaldehyde by-products are formed in the toluene exhaust. Toluene degradation on the catalyst is partially converted to incompletely oxidized intermediates such as aldehydes and organic acids. Additionally, methyl radicals generated during the oxidation of toluene by reactive oxygen species recombine with toluene to form 2,5-dimethylbenzaldehyde. The ring-opening products, such as undecane and sunflower alcohol, are also observed after catalytic ozonation. Based on the above results, it can be deduced that the reactive oxygen species interact with both the CH bond in the methyl group and the CC bond linking the methyl group to the benzene ring, leading to the formation of intermediates that are not fully oxidized. These intermediates include compounds such as benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, and dimethyl benzaldehyde, among others. 3.2.5 Reaction path derivation Ozonolysis is the key to catalytic ozone oxidation of VOCs. It is generally believed that catalytic ozone oxidation of VOCs undergoes a non-homogeneous reaction at the catalyst surface, which follows the Langmuir Hinshelwood (L-H) and Mars-van-Krevelen (Mvk) mechanisms [13,43,44].According to these mechanisms, ozone generates two highly reactive oxygen species during the reaction process: one is O2 -, O2 2-, and O- formed by the decomposition of ozone in contact with the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which is denoted as O*; the other is OH*, which is formed by the reaction of ozone with the water vapor in the system. In this process, there is a cyclic conversion of Mn3+ to Mn4+, with the aim of providing electrons for the oxygen vacancies to activate ozone and generate reactive oxygen species [45]. Based on the structural formula of toluene, the bond energies are as follows: the CH bond energy of the methyl group is 3.7 eV, the CC bond energy of the benzene ring attached to the methyl group is 4.14 eV, and the CH and CC bond energies of the benzene ring are 4.19 eV and 5.0–5.55 eV, respectively [46,47]. Combined with the GC–MS results, a possible pathway for the catalytic oxidation of toluene by Mn/MOR ozone can be deduced as shown in Fig. 8 . The oxidation of toluene initiated at the methyl substituent on the benzene ring. Upon adsorption onto the catalyst surface, the methyl CH bond is preferentially cleaved by reactive oxygen species (ROS), yielding benzyl alcohol. Subsequent oxidation steps convert benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and ultimately to benzoic acid, as delineated in route of Fig. 8 [48]. The second site that is susceptible to oxidation is C6H5 CH3. The methyl group is highly reactive and undergoes three primary reaction pathways. Firstly, it can be rapidly oxidized by ROS to form CO x and H2O [49]. Secondly, due to the electron-deficient nature of the methyl group [50], it can undergo electrophilic substitution with the benzene ring to generate p-xylene and 1,2,5-trimethylbenzene. Subsequently, the ROS generated during the catalytic process further oxidize the methyl groups of 1,2,5-trimethylbenzene [49]. By abstracting hydrogen atoms, benzyl radicals are formed, which are then oxidized to aldehyde groups, ultimately leading to the formation of 2,5-dimethylbenzaldehyde (shown in routes b and c of Fig. 8). Oxygen vacancies continuously provide essential active sites for the decomposition of ozone. Crucially, these consumed oxygen vacancies can be replenished through the interaction between Mn4+ and oxygen to maintain the catalytic activity [51]. 3.3 Effect of regeneration method on reactivity recovery Analysis of the post-reaction catalysts revealed that the primary cause of the decrease in catalytic activity was the accumulation of carbonaceous substance and the loss of Mn3+. Therefore, in this study, four methods were employed to regenerate the post catalyst: (Ⅰ) Calcination at 500 °C for 3 h under nitrogen and air atmospheres respectively; (Ⅱ) Washing with deionized water for 1 hour, followed by centrifugation and drying; (Ⅲ) Stopping the introduction of toluene and introducing 120 ppm of ozone for in-situ regeneration in the reaction system for 3 h. 3.3.1 Performance recovery of different regeneration methods The results of regeneration methods on activity recovery are shown in Fig. 9 . It can be observed that the catalyst calcined in air for 3 h exhibited the highest catalytic activity, with an activity recovery of 94.2 %. This was followed by the catalyst that underwent water washing, with an activity recovery of 83 %. The catalytic performance of the different regeneration methods is ranked as follows: Air > H2O > N2 > Ozone. To further investigate the reasons behind the varying activity recoveries, the catalysts after thermal regeneration and water washing were selected for a series of characterization experiments. 3.3.2 Catalyst characterization after regeneration EDS-mapping was used to scan the changes in elemental contents on the catalyst surface after air thermal regeneration and water washing, as shown in Fig. S4. The results show that the contents of both C and O elements decreased, with air thermal regeneration exhibiting a higher degree of recovery. The C element recovered by 89.8 %, the O element by 99.3 %, and the Mn element by 96 %, which can be attributed to the effective oxidation of carbon deposits on the catalyst surface. By comparing the XRD diffraction peaks of fresh catalysts (Fig. 10 a), it was found that the intensity of the diffraction peaks after air calcination was closest to that of fresh catalysts. This suggests that the carbonaceous material on the catalyst has been oxidized and decomposed. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the catalysts after water washing and Air calcination are shown in Fig. 10b, and the corresponding BET specific surface areas and total pore volumes are shown in Table 5 . The specific surface area recovered by water washing was found to be greater than that after air calcination. Although a large specific surface area has a stronger adsorption capacity, BET is not the only index to evaluate the catalytic performance [52]. Next, the reasons for the better activity recovery of the catalyst after air calcination will be explained by combining the analysis of the catalyst's redox capacity and surface chemistry. The H2-TPR spectra are shown in Fig. 10c. It can be observed that the reduction peak temperature of the catalyst after air calcination is lower than that after water washing, indicating a better recovery of the redox capacity of the post-catalyst. Furthermore, the oxidation capacity can also be inferred from the hydrogen consumption [42]. The hydrogen consumption of the air-calcined catalyst was higher than that of the water-washed catalyst, further confirming that the catalytic performance of the thermally treated catalyst was superior to that of the water-washed catalyst. To illustrate the surface chemistry of the regenerated catalyst, the oxidation states of the catalyst surface elements were analyzed by XPS. The binding energies and the relative content of each Mn valence state are summarized in Table 6 . The relative content of Mn3+ after thermal regeneration is higher, and the Mn3+/Mn percentage reaches 63.16 %. It indicates that the post-catalyst after heating is more favorable for the formation of Mn3+ and promotes the emergence of oxygen vacancies, thus regenerating the activity of catalytic toluene. Fig. S5 shows the XPS spectrum of O1s. The content of O vac is presented in Table 6. The results show that the content of adsorbed oxygen increased more significantly after thermal regeneration than after water washing, which is consistent with the results of the activity test. 3.3.3 Influence of regeneration rate on oxygenated organic deposition Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of deactivated catalysts was performed under N₂ and air atmospheres at heating rates (β) of 5, 10, 15, and 20 K/min (Fig. 11 ). As β increased, the TG curves systematically shifted towards higher temperatures, indicating that achieving equivalent weight loss rates requires elevated temperatures. This thermal lag arises because rapid heating impedes the system's response, necessitating higher temperatures to drive the reaction [53]. Moreover, in an air atmosphere, the combustion of oxygen-containing organic carbon becomes the dominant reaction process due to the participation of oxygen. It can be observed that the DTG curve shifts toward higher temperatures. This phenomenon may arise from the preferential combustion of surface oxygen-containing organic carbon under rapid heating, while the internal oxygen-containing organic carbon experiences delayed reactions due to mass transfer limitations, resulting in thermal hysteresis [54]. Although rapid heating increases the peak intensity of the DTG curve, indicating an accelerated instantaneous decomposition rate of oxygen-containing organic carbon and promoting the combustion process [55], it may also lead to adverse effects such as sintering of active components [56]. In contrast, slow heating reduces the rate of carbon deposit pyrolysis. However, it provides more sufficient oxidation conditions to avoid thermal hysteresis and active component sintering, thus achieving complete oxidation of carbon deposits. The regeneration activation energy (Ea) of deactivated catalysts under air and nitrogen atmospheres was calculated using the Flynn-Wall-Ozawa (FWO) model [57]. According to Formula S1 (Supplementary information), Ea at a constant carbon conversion rate (x,calculated via Formula S2) was derived from the slope of the linear plot of lnβ versus 1/T. By plotting linear regression lines for different atmospheres (Fig. 11), the calculated Ea was 29.16 kJ/mol under the air atmosphere and 47.57 kJ/mol under the nitrogen atmosphere. The significantly lower Ea under the air atmosphere demonstrates its efficacy for efficient carbon deposit oxidation at lower temperatures [58], which is consistent with the activity test results. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of Mn/MOR catalysts with different Mn contents were employed for the ozone oxidation of toluene, and the characterization of catalytic deactivation/regeneration processes for the optimal Mn/MOR catalyst (1 wt. %) was carried out. The relative conclusions were drawn as follows: (1) A 40-hour deactivation experiment showed a decrease in toluene conversion from 92.3 % to 24.3 % and a decrease in CO x selectivity. It was hypothesized that the accumulation of carbon deposits contributed to the catalyst deactivation. (2) During the catalytic process, the decrease in the content of Mn3+ leads to a reduction in oxygen vacancies, preventing toluene and its intermediate products from being oxidized in a timely and effective manner. These substances accumulate in large quantities on the surface of the catalyst, ultimately resulting in catalyst deactivation. (3) Air roasting could effectively recover both the reducibility and content of adsorbed oxygen species, which was attributed to the main reason for the superior recovery of catalytic activity. (4) Although slow heating will slow down the regeneration rate of the deactivated catalyst, it can achieve the complete oxidation of oxygen-containing organic carbon. The present work not only revealed a deactivation mechanism for toluene degradation over Mn-loaded zeolite catalyst during the ozone oxidation process, but also provided an effective strategy for whole-life catalyst management. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation of toluene by ozone at ambient temperature is a promising, energy-efficient method. However, challenges such as catalyst poisoning and deactivation remain significant obstacles. As such, understanding the deactivation mechanisms and the regeneration of catalysts is crucial for optimizing catalytic oxidation processes. This study investigates the deactivation and regeneration processes of Mn/MOR catalysts in the ozone-mediated oxidation of toluene. The highest toluene removal efficiency achieved was 92.3 % with a manganese loading of 1 wt. %, but after eight experimental cycles, the catalytic performance declined to 24.3 %. The deactivation of the catalyst was primarily attributed to the accumulation of by-products during toluene degradation, the loss of Mn3+, and the reduction in oxygen vacancies. Regeneration experiments demonstrated that exposure to hot air effectively oxidized intermediate products and restored the active sites, recovering 94.2 % of the initial catalytic performance. Additionally, the possible reaction pathway for toluene degradation was deduced through GC–MS analysis. This work demonstrates the possibility of recovery of this deactivated catalyst and provides ideas for whole-life catalyst management.
